What radical ideas need in order to flourish, he contends, is sustained, patient debate among committed people with a shared, well-defined ideology. In the past these ideas percolated for a long time in pubs and coffeehouses, pamphlets and small-circulation dissident newspapers, before they burst into public life in the fullness of time. Now, Mr. Beckerman laments, they come and go with regularity on a dizzying array of electronic platforms. "Radical change-change that strips off the stucco and gets to the girders, that offers a chance to see ourselves and our relationship to nature or to others in new ways-doesn't start with yelling," he writes. "It starts with deliberation, a tempo that increases, a volume set first at a whisper."

When French jeweler Cartier made the excessively opulent Patiala Necklace in 1928, it wasn't for a female client. It was commissioned for and worn by the Maharaja Bhupinder Singh of Patiala-and he rocked every single one of its 2,930 diamonds. Throughout known history, men at the height of their power have been inclined to show it off with a little bling. So experimenting with a bracelet here or an extra ring there is really not as wild as you think.

title: Children's Books: A Final Tale From Gary Paulsen
summary: 'Northwind,' the posthumously published tale from the author of 'Hatchet,' sets its survival story in Scandinavia's distant past.. There's a phrase in German, einsfallreicher Erfolg, or "resourceful success," that in the context of books conveys a double satisfaction. It describes the triumph of a character who's thrown into sudden hardship and survives by drawing on valor, ingenuity and whatever tools are at hand. But the expression also captures the reader's vicarious pleasure in watching it all happen. Daniel Defoe was the first to deliver this treat to readers with "Robinson Crusoe" in 1719. In 1812 Johann David Wyss carried on what was developing into a literary genre with "The Swiss Family Robinson." The tradition has continued down the decades to all sorts of novels for young readers, including Scott O'Dell's "Island of the Blue Dolphins" (1960) and Gary Paulsen's modern-day survival classic, "Hatchet" (1986).

"One after another, books were thrown onto the funeral pyre of intellect," the historian Richard J. Evans wrote in "The Coming of the Third Reich," and his phrase is no exaggeration. Works by Einstein, Freud, Mann, Brecht and scores of other "un-German" writers and thinkers were incinerated by Nazi students as zealous onlookers cheered. "The barbarians have taken over," Joseph Roth declared earlier that year in a letter to fellow writer Stefan Zweig. "Do not deceive yourself. Hell reigns." Hitler had just become chancellor and Roth saw what was coming, had in fact seen it all along. An eminent journalist, essayist and novelist who was never fooled-except by love and alcohol-he left for Paris in 1933, his books reduced to ashes on a Berlin street, and remained in exile, always writing, until he collapsed and died-of pneumonia, aided and abetted by drink-in Paris in May 1939 at the age of 44.
